name: triphenylene
Reason: Triphenylene consists of three fused benzene rings resulting in a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH). Benzene, the basic unit, has a melting point of 5.5°C. Fused ring systems significantly increase the melting point due to added pi-pi interactions and increased molecular rigidity, which increases intermolecular forces. The effect of each additional benzene ring can be considered to add approximately 95°C to the melting point of the base benzene unit.

name: triphenylene
Reason: Triphenylene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon with three fused benzene rings. The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. Each additional fused benzene ring significantly increases the melting point due to enhanced pi-pi interactions, greater planarity, and increased molecular rigidity, which in turn lead to stronger intermolecular forces. The incremental effect of each fused benzene ring on the melting point of triphenylene can be estimated to be approximately 64.5°C ([(199-5.5) / 3 rings]).

name: triphenylene
Reason: The basic structure for triphenylene is made up of benzene rings. The melting point of benzene is 5.5°C. Triphenylene is a polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon made up of four fused benzene rings, creating a more rigid and planar structure than a single benzene ring. This increases intermolecular forces, mainly π-π stacking interactions, which leads to a significant increase in melting point. Each additional benzene ring fused to the original could contribute approximately +50°C to the melting point due to enhancements in molecular rigidity and planarity. Therefore, the effect of three additional benzene rings is estimated as +150°C. Additional dispersive forces due to increased molecular size and surface area also contribute to the higher melting point.
